declarations.comments:
A property is just one of the above things: a static property, a property
that depends on some events, or a property that produces events.
declarations.title: Property

declarations.comments:
All the effects that occur as a result of Panda! We'll just use this for
the global signature until the effect row goes...
declarations.title: FX

declarations.comments: A component is either a "static" element, a watcher, a delegate, or text.
declarations.title: Component

declarations.comments:
To create a Panda application, you must specify a view, a controller, and
an initial state (as well as the initial update that will fire on render).
`subscription` allows you to subscribe to external events (but can be
ignored using `Control.Plus.empty`. `update` takes a `dispatch` function
forupdates, and the event that triggered it in the first place. Note the
`dispatch` function takes a _function_ from state - this function
guarantees that your modifications will be applied to the most recent
state. This is helpful when your `update` function gets asynchronous.
declarations.title: Application

declarations.comments:
Run a Panda application. This takes a Panda application and appends it to
the `document.body`, effectively commandeering the entire page. If this
_isn't_ what you want, chances are that you're after `runApplicationIn`,
which will allow you to embed a Panda application inside the DOM. Note
that this function returns a `Maybe`, depending on the presence of `body`,
so this result should be checked to determine whether instantiation was
successful.
declarations.title: runApplication

declarations.comments:
Set up and kick off a Panda application. This creates the element tree,
and ties the update handler to the event stream.
declarations.title: bootstrap

declarations.comments:
Render the "view" of an application. This is the function that actually
produces the DOM elements, and any rendering of a delegate will call
`bootstrap`. This is also where the event handlers and cancellers are
computed.
declarations.title: render

declarations.comments:
Render a Property on a DOM element. This also initialises any `Watcher`
components, and sets up their event handlers and cancellers.
declarations.title: render

declarations.comments:
The shape of a user-supplied renderer. This will most likely be supplied
by the user.
declarations.title: Renderer

declarations.comments: Update something based on whether a particular predicate is satisfied.
declarations.title: watchWhen

declarations.comments:
Watch for a set of actions. This could be seen as a "router" of sorts,
save for the fact that there can be no fallback (as it would be triggered
on every occurrence of any event).
declarations.title: watchSet

declarations.comments: Watch for a particular update.
declarations.title: watchFor

declarations.comments:
Update whenever any event is encountered. In most situations, this isn't
going to be what you want to do, as it's computationally expensive to
re-render the node continually. However, for very simple
(sub)applications, where every possible event is of interest, this might
save you a line or two of code.
declarations.title: watchAny

declarations.comments:
Build a general-purpose watcher. This could be seen as the "advanced"
watcher, because all the other functions are much easier to use.
declarations.title: watch

declarations.comments:
Create a delegate application. Applications can be nested inside other,
larger applications providing that a translation from the update / state /
event types of the inner application to the outer application (this
translation is called a `focus`, as the subapplication can be seen as a
`focus` on one particular part of the wider state.).
declarations.title: delegate

declarations.comments:
The shape of a user-supplied renderer. This will most likely be supplied
by the user.
declarations.title: Renderer

declarations.comments:
Build a general-purpose watcher. This could be seen as the "advanced"
watcher, because all the other functions are much easier to use.
declarations.title: watch

declarations.comments:
Update whenever any event is encountered. In most situations, this isn't
going to be what you want to do, as it's computationally expensive to
re-render the node continually. However, for very simple
(sub)applications, where every possible event is of interest, this might
save you a line or two of code.
declarations.title: watchAny

declarations.comments: Watch for a particular update.
declarations.title: watchFor

declarations.comments:
Watch for a set of actions. This could be seen as a "router" of sorts,
save for the fact that there can be no fallback (as it would be triggered
on every occurrence of any event).
declarations.title: watchSet

declarations.comments: Update something based on whether a particular predicate is satisfied.
declarations.title: watchWhen

declarations.comments: Should we update at all? Or is the DOM fine as it is?
declarations.title: ShouldUpdate

declarations.comments: We're either updating to the new content, or removing the content.
declarations.title: Modification

declarations.comments:
All the effects that occur as a result of Panda! We'll just use this for
the global signature until the effect row goes...
declarations.title: FX

declarations.comments: A canceller cancels some event handler.
declarations.title: Canceller

declarations.comments:
Sum type of all sensible event handlers that can be applied to elements.
Full disclosure: I stole this list from Nate Faubion's wonderful
[purescript-spork](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-spork/)
library.
declarations.title: Producer

declarations.comments:
A static property is just key => value, and can't do anything clever. This
should be used whenever you want to use a property that won't be affectted
by state changes or events.
declarations.title: PropertyStatic

declarations.comments:
A `Watcher` property can vary depending on the state and most recent
update, which allows properties to respond to events. Given an update, a
`Watcher` can `Maybe` decide to update the value. This update is either
`Just` the string to which the property should be set, or that it should
be set to `Nothing` (hence the double-`Maybe`).
declarations.title: PropertyWatcher

declarations.comments:
A producer is a property that... well, produces events! These properties
are indexed by `Producer` values. Using the producer helpers will do you a
lot of favours, as the event has already been coerced to the type
appropriate to that particular DOM action. A particular DOM event can be
ignored if `onEvent` returns a `Nothing`.
declarations.title: PropertyProducer

declarations.comments:
A property is just one of the above things: a static property, a property
that depends on some events, or a property that produces events.
declarations.title: Property

declarations.comments:
A static component is one that has properties and potentially houses other
components. These are the things you _actually_ render to the DOM, and
that get converted to HTML elements. Note that the children of a static
component can absolutely be dynamic, and it can even have dynamic
properties. All this represents is an HTML element.
declarations.title: ComponentStatic

declarations.comments:
A watcher component is one that varies according to the state and updates
in the application loop. Because a re-render is a destructive process, it
is recommended that, the more common the watcher's interest, the lower in
the component tree it should occur. If an event is likely to be fired
every second and that will cause the re-rendering of the entire tree,
performance won't be great.
declarations.title: ComponentWatcher

declarations.comments:
Applications can be nested arbitrarily, with the proviso that there is
some way to translate from "parent" to "child". The actual types of the
child are existential, and are thus not carried up the tree: "as long as
you can tell me how to convert updates and states for the child, and then
'unconvert' events from the child, I can embed this application".
declarations.title: ComponentDelegate

declarations.comments: A component is either a "static" element, a watcher, a delegate, or text.
declarations.title: Component

declarations.comments:
When `Component` or `Property` structures are rendered, an element is
created, along with a system for handling events. This structure houses
that system as a monoid, so that they can be combined more easily.
declarations.title: EventSystem

declarations.comments:
To create a Panda application, you must specify a view, a controller, and
an initial state (as well as the initial update that will fire on render).
`subscription` allows you to subscribe to external events (but can be
ignored using `Control.Plus.empty`. `update` takes a `dispatch` function
forupdates, and the event that triggered it in the first place. Note the
`dispatch` function takes a _function_ from state - this function
guarantees that your modifications will be applied to the most recent
state. This is helpful when your `update` function gets asynchronous.
declarations.title: Application

declarations.comments: Update a property whenever a predicate is satisfied.
declarations.title: watchWhen

declarations.comments: Given a set of predicate/render pairs, update the property accordingly
declarations.title: watchSet

declarations.comments: Watch for a particular update.
declarations.title: watchFor

declarations.comments:
Run a property update regardless of the update that is detected. For
larger applications, this will happen very regularly, so be careful with
this...
declarations.title: watchAny

declarations.comments:
General constructor for property watches. Kind of the "advanced mode" -
use the other functions if possible.
declarations.title: watch

declarations.comments: Event producers
declarations.title: Producer

declarations.comments:
Static properties are those whose `update state event` triple can be
anything.
declarations.title: StaticProperty

declarations.comments: Event conversions
declarations.title: eventToDragEvent

declarations.comments: Specifically build a producer of a given input type.
declarations.title: makeProducer

declarations.comments: Make a producer with the given handler.
declarations.title: makeProducer'

declarations.comments: Get the value of the target DOM element.
declarations.title: targetValue

declarations.comments:
General constructor for property watches. Kind of the "advanced mode" -
use the other functions if possible.
declarations.title: watch

declarations.comments:
Run a property update regardless of the update that is detected. For
larger applications, this will happen very regularly, so be careful with
this...
declarations.title: watchAny

declarations.comments: Watch for a particular update.
declarations.title: watchFor

declarations.comments: Given a set of predicate/render pairs, update the property accordingly
declarations.title: watchSet

declarations.comments: Update a property whenever a predicate is satisfied.
declarations.title: watchWhen

declarations.comments:
The `Exists3` data type is just like `Exists`, except for the fact that it
"houses" three existentials.  For more complete documentation, see the
[Data.Exists](`https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-exists)
package.
declarations.title: Exists3

declarations.comments: Existentialise three type variables.
declarations.title: mkExists3

declarations.comments:
Remove the existential. Note that, when we do this, we have _no idea_ what
the types of these variables are, so we have to handle them with a
function that will work for _all_ types.
declarations.title: runExists3
